text: Might depend on what your motivation is, are you more interested in applications (to what domain then?), or more in pure mathematics, or maybe in the software engineer approach?

elements.text: Might depend on what your motivation is, are you more interested in applications (to what domain then?), or more in pure mathematics, or maybe in the software engineer approach?

text: That's a great question <@UBEF50B7C> - switching to a thread so as to not bung up <#C759LHXV0|graphs> . I suppose for me, I am interested in applications to the realm of bioinformatics but also interested in the mathematics. It may be naieve of me to say, but perhaps a more mathematical approach would be better as I could apply it to specific domains from there? Or pick up from the theoretical and then go off to learn more about the applied?

attachments.title: De Bruijn graph
attachments.text:
In graph theory, an n-dimensional De Bruijn graph of m symbols is a directed graph representing overlaps between sequences of symbols. It has mn vertices, consisting of all possible length-n sequences of the given symbols; the same symbol may appear multiple times in a sequence. If we have the set of m symbols 
  
    
      
        S
        :=
        {
        
          s
          
            1
          
        
        ,
        …
        ,
        
          s
          
            m
          
        
        }
      
    
    {\displaystyle S:=\{s_{1},\dots ,s_{m}\}}
   then the set of vertices is:

  
    
      
        V
        =
        
          S
          
            n
          
        
        =
        {
        (
        
          s
          
            1
          
        
        ,
        …
        ,
        
          s
          
            1
          
        
        ,
        
          s
          
            1
          
        
        )
        ,
        (
        
          s
          
            1
          
        
        ,
        …
        ,
        
          s
          
            1
          
        
        ,
        
          s
          
            2
          
        
        )
        ,
        …
        ,
        (
        
          s
          
            1
          
        
        ,
        …
        ,
        
          s
          
            1
          
        
        ,
        
          s
          
            m
          
        
        )
        ,
        (
        
          s
          
            1
          
        
        ,
        …
        ,
        
          s
          
            2
          
        
        ,
        
          s
          
            1
          
        
        )
        ,
        …
        ,
        (
        
          s
          
            m
          
        
        ,
        …
        ,
        
          s
          
            m
          
        
        ,
        
          s
          
            m
          
        
        )
        }
        .
      
    
    {\displaystyle V=S^{n}=\{(s_{1},\dots ,s_{1},s_{1}),(s_{1},\dots ,s_{1},s_{2}),\dots ,(s_{1},\dots ,s_{1},s_{m}),(s_{1},\dots ,s_{2},s_{1}),\dots ,(s_{m},\dots ,s_{m},s_{m})\}.}
  If one of the vertices can be expressed as another vertex by shifting all its symbols by one place to the left and adding a new symbol at the end of this vertex, then the latter has a directed edge to the former vertex. Thus the set of arcs (that is, directed edges) is

  
    
      
        E
        =
        {
        (
        (
        
          t
          
            1
          
        
        ,
        
          t
          
            2
          
        
        ,
        …
        ,
        
          t
          
            n
          
        
        )
        ,
        (
        
          t
          
            2
          
        
        ,
        …
        ,
        
          t
          
            n
          
        
        ,
        
          s
          
            j
          
        
        )
        )
        :
        
          t
          
            i
          
        
        ∈
        S
        ,
        1
        ≤
        i
        ≤
        n
        ,
        1
        ≤
        j
        ≤
        m
        }
        .
      
    
    {\displaystyle E=\{((t_{1},t_{2},\dots ,t_{n}),(t_{2},\dots ,t_{n},s_{j})):t_{i}\in S,1\leq i\leq n,1\leq j\leq m\}.}
  Although De Bruijn graphs are named after Nicolaas Govert de Bruijn, they were discovered independently by both De Bruijn and I. J. Good. Much earlier, Camille Flye Sainte-Marie implicitly used their properties.

text: Good point <@UBEF50B7C> - also, thanks for the recommendation! :slightly_smiling_face:

There is an excellent book about Directed Graphs that covers most of basic knowledge and then goes deeper.
Digraphs from Jorgen Borg-Jensen. And it happens that Jorgen is a nice guy ...
